title: The World’s Most Meticulous Hitter Plays Cricket
text:
LONDON—The Australian men’s cricket team doesn’t pay attention anymore when Steve Smith tapes his shoelaces to his socks. Nor do they mind being woken up at 7 a.m. by the sound of their teammate tap-tapping his bat on the floor, because he’s decided to practice in his hotel room. After a decade, they barely notice his habit of fidgeting like a murder suspect when he bats.

By now, Australia’s cricketers know that Smith just needs to be left alone.

Because all of the tics, all of the compulsive behavior and eccentric techniques, are part of Smith’s single-minded approach to the art of racking up runs. They have helped make him, without question, the most dangerous batsman in the game. For his obsessive skill and dedication to craft, he is the Mike Trout of Test cricket, the highest form of the game.

But even that doesn’t do him justice. With the attention he brings to his craft, Smith is perhaps the most obsessive striker of a ball in any sport in the world.

“This might sound odd,” said Trent Woodhill, his on-and-off batting coach of 15 years, “but Steven loves batting more than anyone else.”

And more than anyone else, the 30-year-old Smith loves batting against England. His performances in the Ashes, the 137-year-old series between England and Australia, have prompted slews of articles in the British press wondering whether it was even possible to get Smith out. The answer: almost always no.

Through four matches in the 2019 Ashes, Smith has single-handedly scored 29% of Australia’s runs, despite missing 1½ of the matches with a concussion after taking a ball to the head. It turns out that that was more or less the only way to move him, because since the 2019 Ashes began, Smith has dug in to face 998 balls and batted for a combined 26 hours.

In baseball terms, that’s the equivalent of around 250 at-bats. For Steve Smith, it was five innings.

“Not sure [England] know how to bowl to him,” Australian great Shane Warne tweeted during one of Smith’s demolitions.

Through four matches in the 2019 Ashes, Smith has single-handedly scored 29% of Australia’s runs. Photo: carl recine/Reuters

The most galling part for England fans is that Smith was so recently their favorite punching bag. He only returned this summer from a one-year suspension from Test cricket for his part in a ball-tampering scheme involving Australian bowlers and a piece of sandpaper shoved down their pants. Smith, the team’s captain at the time, accepted his ban in a tearful press conference that launched a thousand memes.

Predictably, on his return to England in the first match of the Ashes, Smith was booed mercilessly. Predictably, he also notched a century.

Now, with one more Test to play and Australia already guaranteed to retain the Ashes, his batting average is the third highest in series history, behind only Don Bradman (the Babe Ruth of cricket) and himself. Not that Smith has much time for record books.

“I’m not in the game for personal accolades,” Smith said. “I’m here to do my job and score as many runs for the team as I can.”

Except no one has done his job in this sport quite the way Smith does. Like Stephen Curry or Ichiro Suzuki, Smith’s technique is unique in the sport. Not for its particular beauty—in fact, there’s not much fun to be had actually watching Smith—but for its unorthodoxy.

Beyond his Rafa Nadal-esque routine of patting his pads, cup and helmet before every ball, Smith’s stance sets him apart. Whereas batsmen are traditionally taught to stand just off the stumps and square to the bowler with their bat down, Smith holds his bat cocked and takes a risky step directly across the stumps to better whip his wrists around the ball. (And the taped shoelaces thing is to stop himself from staring at them.) It’s enough to make cricket purists cringe.

For the men who shaped him in the game—his father, Woodhill, and later an Australian coach named Michael Di Venuto—there was never a question of tweaking his mechanics.

“I was more interested in the player than how the player should look,” Woodhill said. “I was around to protect his technique.”

But his ungainly swing helps explain why Smith was never marked for otherworldly batting greatness in his early career. When he was first called up to the Australian national team, in 2010, it was as an all-rounder—someone who could bat and bowl without necessarily specializing. His orders, he said, were to “come into the side and be fun.”

One of Steve Smith’s biggest strength is he never switches off. Photo: carl recine/Reuters

It took three years for him to become a one-man wrecking ball. Beginning in 2013, his numbers exploded. Only the suspension, followed by elbow surgery, slowed him down.

“There were times throughout the last 15 months where I didn’t know if I was ever going to play cricket again,” Smith said during the Ashes. “I lost a bit of love for it at one point, particularly when I had my elbow operation.”

Once the brace came off his elbow, though, he snapped back. “Right I’m ready to go again,” he said.

He is already the 2019 Test season’s leading run-getter, even though his season started in August.

The closest comparison Woodhill could think of for Smith’s relentless consistency was Mike Trout, another supremely gifted hitter obsessed with his craft. But even Trout doesn’t seem as submerged by the moment as Smith. Between balls, Smith has a habit of re-enacting the shot he just made, almost as if to log it in his mind. Then, with a sweep of the arms, he pushes aside what he’s just done and starts the fidgeting process again.

Smith can do this for hours on end. Which is why he’s at his most effective in Test cricket, the game’s five-day format. He has time to outlast bowlers and carefully choose which balls to attack.

Above all, Smith never switches off. Last week in Manchester, windy conditions sent a beach ball rolling from the stands directly into Smith’s path. With all the poise and focus of a man hard-wired to knock balls a long way away, he swept it toward the boundary as if it were a four-run shot.

And obviously, he got it there.

Write to Joshua Robinson at joshua.robinson@wsj.com
description: Steve Smith’s monstrous batting performances have guaranteed that Australia will retain the Ashes against England.
